dict.string: Clear any leftover variables and files from a non-successful run
Set the filenames to use for the UUID files
Test and verify stuff exists before proceeding
If this isn't first run, set some key variables
Set variable for full path to macro database
Set variable for full path to settings database
Get count of folders in backup folder
Check for missing backup folder and handle
Make sure the backups folder exists
if [ ! -d "$KMVAR_rg_MBU_BackupLoc" ]; then echo "backup folder missing"; fi
Run safety checks and read settings from database

dict.string: Make sure the support folder exists
Check for file or folder existing or not
if [ ! -d "$KMVAR_rg_MBU_BackupLoc"/"zSupport Files - Do not delete" ]; then echo "support folder missing"; fi
MacroBackerUpper was unable to locate its support files folder. It has been recreated, and your settings have been reset to default values‚Äîrun the Settings Manager to modify them as needed.
Add the folder for the databases
Parse the Settings database values into variables
Grab the settings from the database
Split the blob settings out into invidual variables
If database and backup location var exist, check database status
if test -f "$KMVAR_rg_MBU_BackupLoc"/"zSupport Files - Do not delete/zDatabase.db"; then echo "exists"; fi

dict.string:
The backup folder is supposed to be located here:
%Variable%rg_MBU_BackupLoc%
However, it couldn't be found. You can either stop the macro now and manually find and move the backup folder, or you can re-run setup as a new user: You'll specify the storage location, set the options as you prefer, and then an initial backup will run. (If you ever do find the missing backups, you can move their folders into the new backup folder location without affecting the macro.)
Click OK to proceed as a new user, or Cancel to end the macro and investigate on your own.
STOP: The backup folder is missing!
Delete the backup folder location so setup will run
Check for backup folder location variable‚Äîif not set, run setup
No backup folder location variable, so run setup

Before your first backup can happen, the macro needs to know only two things...
First, please enter the name you'd like to use for the folder that will hold your macro backups. Each individual backup folder will be stored within this folder, with a date-based name created by the macro.

When the standard file browsing dialog appears, please select the folder where %Variable%localBFName__Name% will reside.
NOTE: The macro will create the folder itself, please don't do so ahead of time.
*** DO NOT USE A NETWORKED OR CLOUD DRIVE! *** I have not tested the macro with such a setup, and I have no idea what may happen.
Next, choose a folder to hold %Variable%localBFName__Name%
Choose the folder that will store %Variable%localBFName__Name%
Set global variable to the backup folder location
This should never ever be true, but let's check anyway

Given you've just set it, this should be impossible.
MBU will now cancel; please contact Rob using the link in the 'Info: Read Me First!' macro, and let him know you saw this message. (It really shouldn't ever appear!)
Error: Backup folder location is empty
Create the folder to hold the backups
A quick first check to see if the folder was created
If the first check didn't find the folder, let's wait a bit and see if it shows up
Test for folder's existence, with a timeout limit
Show a notification, but just once
Check if the loop exit was due to the timeout, if so, warn and cancel

MacroBackerUpper cannot find the backups folder which should have been created, which indicates something has gone wrong.
MBU will now cancel; please contact Rob using the link in the 'Info: Read Me First!' macro, and let him know you saw this message. (It really shouldn't ever appear!)
Failed to find folder within five seconds
Add the support files folder to the backups folder
Set variable for full path to macro database
Set variable for full path to settings database
Add the folder for the database
Create the Settings database and populate with default values

MacroBackerUpper has what it needs to create your first backup. Many more settings are available, with their defaults [shown in brackets]:
‚Ä¢ Control timing notifications [end of run notification] ‚Ä¢ See detailed timing on saved backup report [no] ‚Ä¢ Use hard links to save drive space [yes] ‚Ä¢¬†How many backups to keep [30] ‚Ä¢¬†When to see onscreen info windows [always] ‚Ä¢ Use Finder labels to show status [yes] ‚Ä¢ Change the startup delay before backups begin [3 seconds]
Choose Set Now to customize each of those now, or Set Later to do so in the Settings Manager when you wish.
That's all that's required for now
Walk through detailed setup if user wants to, otherwise read defaults in

MacroBackerUpper tracks time taken during each part of the backup. You can choose how much of this data you'd like to see:
‚Ä¢¬†Notification: You'll see one notification at the end of the run, showing the total time taken. ‚Ä¢ Window: As above, but the information is presented in a window, not a notification. ‚Ä¢ Silence: There is no end-of-run notification of any sort. ‚Ä¢ All: Every task creates a notification‚Äînot recommended!
The default is Notification.
How much timing data would you like to see?
Translate answer into the timer's language
Timing: Show or hide on final report

If you say yes, the last section of the backup report will show exactly how much time each portion of the backup task took‚Äîthe summary dialog reports the total time, but the detailed report shows it for each main task. (The times are calculated regardless of your answer here, but they add roughly three hundredths of a second in overhead time.)
This is completely useless information‚Äîthere's nothing you can do about the reported times, but some might like to see it (in a geeky kinda way). The default is no.
Include detailed backup timing on report?

If you say yes, the macro will replace any identical macros and macro groups with hard links to the original backup of that macro or group. What is a hard link? It's like a Finder alias, sort of:
https://eclecticlight.co/2018/03/12/aliases-links-clones-and-bookmarks/
Hard links save a *ton* of drive space, but there are some downsides:
‚Ä¢ If you copy the backups to another drive in Finder, the hard links will become real files, instantly swelling the size of your backups folder. (You can avoid this issue with rsync; see the "Read Me First!" macro.)
‚Ä¢¬†Finder will report incorrect size values for your backups, as it sees each folder as taking space as if each file were real. MacroBackerUpper will tell you the actual space used (in total and per backup) when each backup completes.
I recommend you say yes, as the space savings are dramatic‚Äîon the order of 10x or more. (You can change this setting at any time, but existing backups will not be switched.)
Do you want to use hard links?
Set upcoming dialog text based on hard links answer

Thanks to hard links, each backup isn't overly large, so more is better. As an example, 10 backups of a 550 macro collection requires under 20MB of drive space. You must have a minimum of two backups in order to see a comparison report.
To keep all your backups, enter any negative number.
I recommend a negative number, as you can always manually prune the older backups if you wish.

Without hard links, each backup will be full sized. How large that is depends on your macro collection. With 550 macros across 70ish groups, my export is about 18MB, so 30 backups would require 540MB of drive space.
To keep all your backups, enter any negative number.
If you're tight on drive space, you may want to set a low limit, but even at their largest, the backups won't take a ton of room.
How many backup sets would you like to keep?
Summary dialog: When to show or hide
Show what the dialog looks like

By default, the dialog box shown at top left appears after each run. You can opt to always have it displayed, only have it displayed when you trigger the macro in the editor or via hot key, or to never see it.
A notification always appears when the macro finishes, so the onscreen dialog is mainly useful for the disk space usage information it contains.

MacroBackerUpper uses Finder labels to help you distinguish what's changed in each backup. Yellow macro group folder contain modified macros; green ones are new; gray ones are identical to the last backup; etc. A full list can be found on the help page linked in the Info: Read Me First! macro.
Finder labels are on by default, but you can disable them if you'd prefer.
Do you want to use Finder labels?

MacroBackerUpper won't start the backup the instant you launch it. By default, it pauses three seconds, which gives you time to cancel the backup, or to enter the Settings Manager, where you can change various settings, including this one. You can change this to any number you like, as long as it's at least one (integers only, please).
Pause for how long before beginning backup?
Write new settings to the database

UPDATE s_MacroBackerUpper SET Backup_Qty = %Variable%instance_BackupQty%, Hard_Links = '%Variable%instance_UseHardLinks%', Show_Timing = '%Variable%instance_ShowTiming%', Show_Summary = '%Variable%instance_ShowDialog%', Use_Labels = '%Variable%instance_UseLabels%', Timer_Delay = %Variable%instance_TimerDelay%, Timing_Mode = '%Variable%instance_TimingNotify%'
Parse the Settings database values into variables
Grab the settings from the database
Split the blob settings out into invidual variables
